annotation.text:
Red cross visit to Terezin.  Curtains.  Cleaned up- sheets, etc. from transports.  Had to write postcards home- told what to write.  Saw Swedish Red Cross, not from Switzerland- but not allowed to talk to them.  Mixed marriage prisoners permitted to receive postcards from family and could also write once a month {I show postcard}, had to be thirty words or less- I read card- could only write in German {I translate  into English} {I cry}.  Another card to husband from daughter.

Terezin- conditions

Barracks- work when didn't have mica work, made to clean the town.  Hospital, sheets, etc.

Typhus vaccines, got diarrhea from it.  Once meat from sick horse, all got sick- not enough latrines.  The Austrian Scharfuhrer who gave the meat was punished and taken away.  Shower- allowed, but had to pay for with ghetto money.

Fire in Terezin- Scharfuhrer set it to make us work.

Madness in Terezin, one building, when you passed by you heard yelling and screaming.  Seventeen-year-old girl in my transport went crazy; I never saw her again.  Witnessed abuses {I describe}.  Jewish husbands of Christian women- when wives divorced them were shipped to Auschwitz.

Escape from Terezin.  With man she I from Sudetenland, also of mixed marriage.  Taken on French trucks and walking and train, made way home.

Husband- found him very sick.  Reunion with children- smaller daughter didn't recognize me.  Husband recovered physically, but never mentally.

In 1947 when we went to South America he was very unhappy.  Could never attach to a new life.  Moved back into old apartment, but most belongings stolen.  Collected daughters-  was limping, in pain.

Man who escaped with me went from camp to camp looking for his children, who were Jewish. When he heard they were killed, he shot himself.  Germans called it "auf der flucht erschossen," but it wasn't true.  Women with typhus happy to be reunited with her husband and three year old child, only to die of the typhus she had contracted by kissing her sister through the wire.

Husband- died four years after we moved to Argentina.  Couldn't adjust.  Died of cancer.  I was a widow for 33 years, two children, not much restitution.  Worked very hard in Argentina.  My children had no real childhood, both had to work from the age of 14.

?Did you meet any Nazis in Argentina?
No, but there were.  A rabbi's child was shot by a German.  Anti-Semites broke into a Jewish orphanage in Argentina and slashed children's faces with razor blades.  The antisemitism in Argentina made my husband very unhappy.
